body:
I guess it's an ok change, however we cannot accept the pull request - the repo cannot accept it and we need your approval to take your code as a patch on jira.

If you open a bug and put the patch there, we'll take it. Thanks!
ok! thanks! I'll try to do so.
is this PR dead ? It sounds interresting (even if I don't use mercurial, buildr should be able to do it)
Unfortunately we require patches to be submitted to jira. However you have done this so the patch has been merged in trunk.
I believe this pull request has been merged into trunk

Thanks for that. The fix has been applied in https://github.com/apache/buildr/commit/f7fdfba619109837fee303d50adb55ed7f25861c

If this is fine could you close off this issue - thanks!
Do you want me to close this PR?

in the changelog, for version 1.4.8 (2012-11-01) we can read :
- Added:  BUILDR-645 Support Mercurial as a version control system (Tan Quach)

Reply from Humbedooh on #asfbot on Freenode (IRC):
FWIW, you can close PRs yourself. Instructions are in the email you receive when a new pull request is made.

BTW, I can't run spec here : 

``` bash
$ rake spec
Compiling Java libraries ...
ruby1.9.1 /home/jp/src/open_source/buildr/_buildr --buildfile buildr.buildfile compile
(in /home/jp/src/open_source/buildr, development)
Compiling buildr
Compiling buildr:scala into lib/buildr/scala
VScalaDoc not supported for Scala 2.8+
Downloading org.scala-lang:scala-reflect:jar:2.9.2
Buildr aborted!
RuntimeError : Failed to download org.scala-lang:scala-reflect:jar:2.9.2, tried the following repositories:
http://oss.sonatype.org/content/repositories/releases/
https://oss.sonatype.org/content/groups/scala-tools/
http://repo1.maven.org/maven2/
https://oss.sonatype.org/content/groups/scala-tools/

(See full trace by running task with --trace)
rake aborted!
Command failed with status (1): [ruby1.9.1 /home/jp/src/open_source/buildr/...]
/home/jp/src/open_source/buildr/rakelib/package.rake:28:in `block in <top (required)>'
Tasks: TOP => spec => compile
(See full trace by running task with --trace)
```
this is a (possibly better) alternative to https://github.com/apache/buildr/pull/12
sorry I did'n sync my repo this morning; maybe a cherry-pick instead of a merge (if this patch is okay), otherwise commit history will become a mess ?
It's really great to see progress on this project. I was kind of afraid that it had been abandoned. Thanks a lot for your effort!
No problem. Please join us in voting the release, we need people testing the RC.

I like the idea. 

How does it impact people who were using rspec within their buildfiles. Is the old syntax supported? i.e. That documented at https://github.com/apache/buildr/blob/master/doc/testing.textile#testing-your-build

If we can't support the old syntax maybe we should document it clearly and bump the version to 1.5

This is targeting 1.5. It only impacts our specs - migrating them from v2 to v4.

All specs pass locally with those changes, so it looks like we're either not testing this functionality or it's not affected by my changes. Either way, I'll go back and check.

I am not completely sure this buys us much to upgrade just for the sake of it, though it looks like some new versions of other libs require a newer rspec.
Also, this branch contains invalid commits, since I recreated the 1.4.24 commit. I will recreate the branch after 1.4.24 is out.
The specs certainly seem easier to read in this form...
I never got around to pushing this in, but it's certainly possible to just rerun the same steps. Closing.
@realityforge do you want to take a look at the changes? I took the easy route and just moved files around. Specs pass locally.
Looks good to me. We can remove the ugly patching of artifacts as a next step.
@realityforge Would you prefer a split-out RSpec `shared_examples` change?

It certainly would not hurt. I was just going to spend sometime to see if I could figure out what the other build failures are and address them at the same time. Unfortunately  I probably won't have the bandwidth till Friday :/

Great - I have merged this in but it seems like there is some problems in our TravisCI build and has been for a while which is completely independent of this change. I will try and get the time to get the build back working. It seems to be related to changes in RubyGems api over time
I apologize for being unclear: Lots of commits I could have squashed.
No problem - thanks for the contribution ;)
Thanks - I did not know you could do this!
